questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above Regional anesthesia means blocking a region of the body. Nerve blocks are given to block the region of the body. Nerve blocks are classified as peripheral nerve blocks and central neuraxial blocks. Central neuraxial blocks are blocks given along the central neuraxis and include spinal, epidural, saddle, and caudal. All other blocks are considered peripheral nerve blocks. Among the peripheral nerve blocks, the brachial plexus block is most often employed for upper limb surgeries.

questions.text: Stellate ganglion block is not done in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anhidrosis Stellate ganglion block is given for hyperhidrosis

Highyeild:

Stellate ganglion block is performed for upper limb reflex sympathetic dystrophies (now called complex regional pain syndrome) which includes diseases mediated by sympathetic over an activity like: Raynaud’s disease Causalgia phantom limb Burger disease Sudek osteodystrophy Other indications of stellate ganglion block may include: Hyperhidrosis Intra-arterial Thiopentone injection Vasospasm following arterial cannulation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old girl is suffering from complex regional pain syndrome, causalgia, following a road traffic accident. The patient has already received the maximum doses of all medications therefore the pain specialist decided to give stellate ganglion to this patient. All of the following statements regarding satellite ganglion block are true except.

options.label: A
options.text: Chassaignac tubercle which is the tubercle of the transverse process of C7 is the landmark to give stellate ganglion block

options.label: B
options.text: A successful block will be accompanied by Horner syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Conjunctival congestion is usually the first sign of a successful block

options.label: D
options.text: Guttamann’s sign is nasal stuffiness which can occur after a successful stellate ganglion block

questions.correct_answer: A. Chassaignac tubercle which is the tubercle of the transverse process of C7 is the landmark to give stellate ganglion block
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chassaignac tubercle which is the tubercle of the transverse process of C7 is the landmark to give stellate ganglion block The stellate ganglion is blocked anterior to the tubercle of the transverse process of the C6 (not C7) vertebra called as Chassaignac tubercle.

Highyeild:

Signs of the successful block include Horner syndrome Flushing of face Conjunctival congestion- Nasal stuffiness Increased skin temperature Congestion of the tympanic membrane

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: B. Horner syndrome which is a sign of successful block is characterized by: Miosis Enophthalmos Ptosis Anhidrosis Absence of pupillary dilatation Absence of ciliospinal reflex. Option: C. Conjunctival congestion is usually the earliest sign of a successful block Option: D. Nasal stuffiness is called Guttamann’s sign while congestion of the tympanic membrane is called Mullers sign.

questions.text: Not a complication of stellate ganglion block:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tachycardia Due to blockage of cardioaccelerator fibers, there occurs bradycardia

Highyeild:

Complications of stellate ganglion block are: Paralysis of the recurrent laryngeal and phrenic nerve. Brachial plexus involvement. Spinal/epidural. Hematoma, vascular injection Injury to the pharynx, larynx Pneumothorax.

questions.text: The brachial plexus is a commonly employed peripheral nerve block utilized for upper limb surgeries. All of the following statements regarding brachial plexus block given through interscalene route are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Drug is injected between the anterior and middle scalene

options.label: C
options.text: Phrenic nerve may be blocked in half of the cases

questions.correct_answer: C. Phrenic nerve may be blocked in half of the cases
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phrenic nerve may be blocked in half of the cases Phrenic nerve block is almost inevitable in the Interscalene approach. It is seen by almost 100% of the patients.

Highyeild:

The brachial plexus can be blocked through 4 routes Interscalene Supraclavicular Infraclavicular Axillary

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. In the interscalene approach, the brachial plexus is blocked between the anterior and middle scalene. Option: C. Ulnar nerve is usually spared when the brachial plexus is blocked through an interscalene approach. Therefore, this approach is not suitable for hand surgeries

Extraedge:

The unilateral phrenic nerve block is not a bothersome complication in normal subjects. It just reduces the vital capacity by 10-20% which has no consequences in healthy patients. However, this can be problematic in compromised patients.

questions.text: A 20-year male was undergoing surgery for humerus plating under the supraclavicular brachial plexus block. After 15-20 minutes he developed severe dyspnea, and oxygen saturation started falling. The first measure to be taken is:

options.label: C
options.text: Put a large bore needle in 2nd intercostal space

questions.correct_answer: C. Put a large bore needle in 2nd intercostal space
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Put a large bore needle in 2nd intercostal space The patient has developed tension pneumothorax therefore putting the needle in 2 nd (or 4 th or 5 th space as practiced more commonly nowadays) should be done as a life saving measure.

Highyeild:

The incidence of pneumothorax may be as high as 1 to 6% when brachial plexus is blocked through supraclavicular route. Fortunately, most of these pneumothoraces resolve by themselves without treatment. Usually, pneumothorax becomes significant in the situations where the effect of the block is not adequate and patients receive During GA positive pressure ventilation can convert a simple pneumothorax into tension pneumothorax.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. IPPV can increase pneumothorax and can convert a small pneumothorax into large pneumothorax. Therefore, if needed then IPPV should be started only after putting a chest drain. Option: B. Oxygen by mask is not sufficient for the treatment of pneumothorax Option: D. A desaturating patient cannot be observed even for a minute.

questions.text: Supraclavicular approach is the most commonly employed approach for brachial plexus blocks. All of the following statements are true about brachial plexus block blocked through supraclavicular approach except:

options.label: A
options.text: Pneumothorax is the most common complication

options.label: B
options.text: During injection the direction of needle should be lateral to subclavian artery

options.label: C
options.text: The point of insertion is just above the midpoint of clavicle

questions.correct_answer: A. Pneumothorax is the most common complication
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pneumothorax is the most common complication Although pneumothorax is a complication of main concerns, the phrenic nerve gets blocked in almost half of the patients during supraclavicular block, however unilateral phrenic nerve block is not a complication of concern in normal patients.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: B. The dome of pleura lies on medial side therefore the best approach to avoid pneumothorax is that needle should be lateral to subclavian artery and facing the ipsilateral nipple Option: C. The point of injection is the midpoint of the clavicle which is taken as the point at which the subclavian artery is felt.

Solution:

Musculocutaneous With axillary approach musculocutaneous and intercostobrachial nerves are spared so arm surgeries or surgeries requiring tourniquet in arm cannot be performed under axillary approach without separately blocking these nerves.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. Ulnar nerve gets spared in interscalene approach Options: B, D. Radial and median nerve gets blocked in all four approaches employed to block brachial plexus

questions.text: A 50-year male with no history of medical illness was given Bier’s block for debridement of hand. All of a sudden after 2-3 minutes the patient's BP recorded was 70/50 mmHg and collapsed. The most probable reason would have been:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tourniquet deflation Bier’s block is also called intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA). It was first described by August Bier, that’s why it is called Bier's block. In this block 30-40 ml of drug is directly given in a peripheral vein after inflating tourniquet. If the tourniquet gets deflated such high volume will reach the circulation and the patient can collapse immediately. This is the most important reason for which Bier’s block is not employed routinely.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. As patient does not have any history of MI so getting new MI is rare. Moreover, the patient will complain of chest pain or at least uneasiness before becoming hemodynamically unstable Option: C. Drug anaphylaxis will occur after some time and the patient along with hypotension will have bronchospasm, laryngospasm Option: D. Surgery has not yet been started (even painting and draping takes 10-15 minutes), so there is no reason that the patient will develop bleeding and hypovolemia.

questions.text: A 30 -year- old lady is to undergo surgery under intravenous regional anesthesia for her left trigger finger. Which one of the following should not be used for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bupivacaine The most dreadful complication of Biers block is tourniquet deflation leading to drug toxicity. Bupivacaine has very high cardiotoxic potential, once there occurs cardiac arrest after bupivacaine, it becomes almost impossible to revive the patient therefore Bupivacaine is absolutely contraindicated for biers block.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: Option: A. Lignocaine 0.5% is the most commonly used drug for Bier’s block. Option: C. Prilocaine is considered as safe drug and can be used for Biers block however its generally not available. Moreover, the intravenous injection can cause methemoglobinemia Option: D. Although diluted concentration of ropivacaine has been used by many clinicians however generally is avoided because it is still more toxic than lignocaine

Extraedge:

As the drug is injected intravenously, preservative-free preparation of lignocaine i.e., Xylocard should be preferred over lignocaine with preservative

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of the Bier block, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Very safe Due to the risk of systemic toxicity, Bier block is not considered a safe block

Highyeild:

The advantages of Bier block are: Rapid onset. Very high success rate. Good muscle relaxation. Easy procedure. Disadvantages are: Venous engorgement creates difficulty in providing bloodless Accidental deflation and leak can cause drug toxicity and death. Compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient underwent a lower segment cesarean section under general anesthesia. The patient had requested good postoperative analgesia. Therefore, as a part of a multimodal approach you decided to give a Transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block in addition to routine analgesics. During the TAP block, the drug should be injected between:
questions.correct_answer: C. External oblique and transversus abdominis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

External oblique and transversus abdominis The transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block is a very frequently used block for producing analgesia for lower abdominal surgeries. It involves the administration of local anesthetic between the External oblique and transversus abdominis to block ilioinguinal and iliohypogastric nerves. Although it can be given blindly however it is almost always given under ultrasound guidance

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient with uncontrolled diabetes and myocardial ischemia on clopidogrel is to be operated on for amputation of the great toe. The anesthetic technique of choice would be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ankle block An ankle block is the best choice for this patient.

Random:

EXPLANATION FOR INCORRECT OPTIONS: Options: A and B. In this case, the patient cannot receive spinal/epidural as he is on clopidogrel, which is an absolute contraindication of the central neuraxial block. Patients on anticoagulants or antiplatelets can develop a significant hematoma (which can even cause paraplegia) if there occurs traumatic spinal/epidural Option: C. Femoral nerve does not supply the area where surgery is to be done.

Extraedge:

In the ankle block deep peroneal, superficial peroneal, and saphenous nerve are blocked at the ankle.

questions.text: In Paravertebral block, the drug can spread to all of the following sites except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subarachnoid space Drugs cannot enter the subarachnoid space until the dura is not punctured.

Highyeild:

The paravertebral space is a wedge-shaped anatomical compartment adjacent to the vertebral bodies. Its boundaries are defined anterior-laterally by the parietal pleura; posteriorly by the superior costotransverse ligament (thoracic levels); medially by the vertebrae, vertebral disk, and intervertebral foramina. The paravertebral block is given either for surgeries like mastectomy, nephrectomy (where GA is not possible), or for pain relief for surgeries or painful conditions. Complications from paravertebral blocks include inadvertent vascular puncture, hypotension, hematoma, epidural spread (via nerve sheath) spread to superior and inferior intercostal spaces and to other side through prevertebral space (if large volumes are used)

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for giving peripheral nerve blocks? Patient on warfarin Patient on Dabigatran Patient on low molecular weight heparin Patient on Aspirin Select the correct answer from the below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 3 are correct 1, 2, and 3 - Patients on anticoagulants or heparin should not be given nerve blocks otherwise they can bleed profusely after traumatic injury to vessels. Moreover, the majority of blocks are deep where it is difficult to control bleeding by applying external pressure 4- Patients on aspirin can not only receive peripheral blocks but central neuraxial blocks can also be safely given in patients on aspirin
